Headline: Swiggy launches new standalone app SNACC. Here's all you need to know The app, which is currently available in select Bengaluru neighbourhoods, is aimed at urban consumers who prioritise speed and convenience when it comes to food delivery.
Content: Bengaluru-based food delivery company Swiggy has launched a new app called SNACC, which is focused on delivering snacks, beverages, and quick meals within 10 to 15 minutes. The app, which is currently available in select Bengaluru neighbourhoods, is aimed at urban consumers who prioritise speed and convenience when it comes to food delivery. The SNACC app offers a menu that includes breakfast options, light meals, and a variety of beverages, perfect for those seeking a fast, hassle-free dining experience. The app can be downloaded on both Android and iOS platforms, signaling Swiggy’s foray into the ultra-fast food delivery space, a market segment that's growing rapidly. This launch marks a shift from Swiggy's traditional model, where innovations were integrated into its main app, which has grown increasingly cluttered and difficult to navigate. By creating SNACC as a standalone platform, the company aims to streamline the delivery process for those looking for quick bites without the distractions of larger food orders. SNACC expands on Swiggy’s existing success with its rapid delivery arm, Bolt, which promises 15-minute deliveries by partnering with restaurants that can meet strict delivery time requirements. Unlike Bolt, however, SNACC operates from a centralised hub stocked with ready-to-serve products, enabling even faster and more reliable service. With this move, Swiggy is entering a competitive arena, where rivals like Zepto Cafe and Blinkit Bistro are already making waves in the rapid food delivery market. These platforms have capitalised on the increasing demand for quick, convenient food options, especially among India’s millennials and Gen Z consumers. India’s rapid food delivery market has seen significant growth, driven by changing consumer preferences and the widespread adoption of digital services. However, the sector faces its share of challenges, including high operational costs and the pressure to deliver quality food while meeting tight delivery windows.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 8, 2025Trending Reel

Headline: GDP growth in FY25 may hit 4-year low. Is Indian economy losing steam?While a slowdown in the ongoing financial year was anticipated, the steep downward revision in GDP growth for FY25 has taken many by surprise.
Content: India’s economic growth is expected to slow sharply to 6.4% in FY25, according to the first advance estimates released by the government. The  projection marks a considerable drop from the 8.2% growth achieved in FY24 and represents the slowest pace of expansion in four years. The estimate is also lower than the Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) revised annual growth forecast of 6.6%, raising concerns across sectors. While a slowdown in the ongoing financial year was anticipated, the steep downward revision has taken many by surprise. So, what factors are driving this deceleration in GDP growth?advertisementSECTORAL GROWTH MODERATIONDr. Manoranjan Sharma, Chief Economist at Infomerics Ratings, explained, “India’s GDP is expected to grow by 6.4% in FY25 over 7.2% in FY24. This slowest growth rate since the pandemic manifests moderation across key sectors and constitutes a significant drop from the 8.2% growth in FY24.”While agriculture is poised for a noticeable improvement with a growth projection of 3.8% compared to 1.4% last year, other key sectors are forecast to slow. Manufacturing growth is projected to fall to 5.3% from 9.9%, while mining is expected to grow at 2.9% compared to 7.1%.Similarly, the construction sector is set to grow at 8.6%, down from 9.9%, and electricity growth is estimated at 6.8%, lower than the previous year’s 7.5%.The top contributors to GDP, such as manufacturing, trade and hotels, and financial services and real estate, are all expected to witness slower growth in FY25. Urban consumption has also been hit hard, with inflation eroding the purchasing power of the urban poor.“Decelerating GDP growth, together with persistent inflation, would make the RBI’s task of managing the growth-inflation trade-off odious,” added Dr. Sharma.CHANGING CONSUMER PREFERENCES Dr. Manoranjan Sharma, Chief Economist at Infomerics Ratings, explained, “India’s GDP is expected to grow by 6.4% in FY25 over 7.2% in FY24. This slowest growth rate since the pandemic manifests moderation across key sectors and constitutes a significant drop from the 8.2% growth in FY24.”While agriculture is poised for a noticeable improvement with a growth projection of 3.8% compared to 1.4% last year, other key sectors are forecast to slow. Manufacturing growth is projected to fall to 5.3% from 9.9%, while mining is expected to grow at 2.9% compared to 7.1%. While agriculture is poised for a noticeable improvement with a growth projection of 3.8% compared to 1.4% last year, other key sectors are forecast to slow. Manufacturing growth is projected to fall to 5.3% from 9.9%, while mining is expected to grow at 2.9% compared to 7.1%. Similarly, the construction sector is set to grow at 8.6%, down from 9.9%, and electricity growth is estimated at 6.8%, lower than the previous year’s 7.5%. The top contributors to GDP, such as manufacturing, trade and hotels, and financial services and real estate, are all expected to witness slower growth in FY25. Urban consumption has also been hit hard, with inflation eroding the purchasing power of the urban poor. “Decelerating GDP growth, together with persistent inflation, would make the RBI’s task of managing the growth-inflation trade-off odious,” added Dr. Sharma.CHANGING CONSUMER PREFERENCES Dr. VP Singh, a director at Great Lakes Institute of Management, highlighted the impact of evolving consumer behaviour on economic growth. “Premiumisation is the flavour of the day. The industry will have to quickly adapt to changing tastes,” he noted. Singh pointed out that subdued sales in the FMCG and auto sectors are not merely a result of low incomes. “The entry of brands like MG Hector and KIA in 2018 and the surge in Parle-G sales during COVID indicate that poor sales stem more from shifting preferences than income constraints,” he said. These shifts in consumer behaviour underline a broader transition in India’s consumption landscape, which may weigh on GDP growth in the short term but could offer opportunities for industries willing to adapt quickly. “The country is undergoing a change in preferences, and the industry will soon incorporate these changes, leading to more robust GDP growth,” Singh added.IMPACT ON STOCK MARKETS AND BROADER ECONOMY Ajit Mishra, SVP, Research, Religare Broking Ltd, highlighted the potential market impact of the revised GDP forecast. “India’s GDP growth projection of 6.4% for FY25 could temper investor sentiment, as lower growth expectations might lead to reduced corporate earnings forecasts, prompting portfolio adjustments,” he said. Sectors closely tied to economic growth, particularly manufacturing, may see notable declines. However, Mishra suggested that “effective government fiscal measures or potential interest rate cuts by the RBI could offer some relief.” A sustained slowdown in GDP growth could also affect foreign institutional investor (FII) sentiment. Mishra noted, “Slower economic growth often raises concerns about corporate profitability and market stability. If FIIs identify more favourable opportunities elsewhere, they may reduce their exposure to Indian equities.” That said, India’s long-term appeal remains intact due to its demographic advantage, strong consumption trends, and resilient financial markets. External factors such as global economic conditions and geopolitical tensions will also play a role in shaping FII behaviour. Nominal GDP is expected to grow by 9.7% in FY25, slightly higher than the 9.6% seen in FY24. However, the broader economic outlook will rely heavily on the government’s fiscal policies and the RBI’s approach to managing inflation and growth.Published By: Koustav DasPublished On: Jan 8, 2025Must Watch

Headline: RBI's new credit reporting rules: Check how it will affect loan borrowersFrom January 1, 2025, RBI's bi-monthly credit updates aim to boost credit scores, empower borrowers, and improve lender risk assessments.
Content: Starting January 1, 2025, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has mandated lenders to update credit bureau records every 15 days, a shift from the previous monthly cycle. This new regulation aims to provide a more accurate reflection of borrowers' financial activities, enhancing credit score precision and streamlining financial assessments.TIMELY UPDATES FOR BETTER CREDIT SCORES Under the older system, credit bureaus relied on monthly updates from lenders, leading to delays in capturing borrowers' repayment behaviour. For instance, timely payments or loan closures often went unrecognised until the next update, potentially impacting borrowers' credit scores and limiting their access to favourable loan terms. The new 15-day cycle ensures faster updates, allowing borrowers’ financial activities to be reflected in real-time, thereby improving their chances of securing better credit opportunities.IMPROVED CREDIT RISK ASSESSMENT The bi-monthly update system benefits lenders by offering more current credit data. This enables them to assess credit risk accurately, identify potential defaulters sooner, and reward responsible borrowers promptly. With up-to-date information, lenders can make well-informed decisions when evaluating loan applications, fostering responsible borrowing habits and reducing default rates.KEY BENEFITS OF THE NEW REGULATION Timely updates: Borrowers' credit histories will now reflect their financial activities more quickly, benefiting those with consistent repayment habits. Enhanced credit access: Accurate credit scores allow responsible borrowers to access loans faster and on better terms. Consumer empowerment: Real-time updates offer borrowers greater insight into their financial health, promoting informed decision-making. Lender confidence: Frequent updates improve risk management, providing a clearer picture of borrowers' financial behaviour. With the new bi-monthly updates, borrowers gain from quicker acknowledgement of their financial behaviours, while lenders benefit from improved risk assessment tools. This regulatory change not only strengthens trust in India's lending system but also empowers consumers and promotes a more equitable financial environment.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 8, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Budget 2025: Easier ITR filing and tax dispute reduction expected, says reportBudget 2025 aims to simplify tax filing, reduce disputes, and foster a transparent, taxpayer-friendly system.
Content: The upcoming Union Budget 2025-26 is poised to introduce significant changes to India's tax landscape, aiming to simplify income tax filing and address longstanding tax disputes. According to a Bloomberg report, Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman is expected to unveil a comprehensive overhaul of the Income Tax Act, 1961, a move that has been in the works for several months.advertisementKEY FOCUS: SIMPLIFYING TAX FILINGThe proposed reforms, which may be open for public consultation by mid-January, are designed to streamline the income tax return (ITR) filing process. The proposed reforms, which may be open for public consultation by mid-January, are designed to streamline the income tax return (ITR) filing process. The initiative includes simplifying tax computation structures with formulas, unifying the definitions of the assessment year and financial year, and introducing tabular formats for taxpayer clarity. While the changes aim to make tax compliance easier, the government has indicated that tax rates and policies will remain unchanged. The demand for a simpler tax regime has grown, especially with tax disputes ballooning to Rs 10.5 lakh crore by the fiscal year ending March 2023. The proposed changes aim to address these disputes and provide clarity to taxpayers, reducing litigation and improving compliance.STEPS TOWARD REFORM In her July 2024 Budget speech, Sitharaman highlighted the government’s commitment to simplifying taxation. Measures like the introduction of exemption-free tax regimes for corporations and individuals have already garnered positive feedback, with 58% of corporate tax revenue in 2022-23 coming from the simplified regime. Similarly, over two-thirds of taxpayers have adopted the new system. The Income Tax Department has also received over 6,500 suggestions from stakeholders, reflecting widespread public engagement in shaping the reforms.A MORE TRANSPARENT TAX REGIME As India prepares for Budget 2025, these reforms signal a step toward a more transparent and taxpayer-friendly system. By reducing complexity and fostering clarity, the government aims to create a tax framework that promotes trust and compliance. With these anticipated changes, taxpayers can look forward to a smoother filing experience and fewer disputes.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 8, 2025Tune InMust Watch

Headline: Budget 2025: What is Economic Survey, when it's released, and why it mattersThe Economic Survey offers key insights into India's economy, guiding the Union Budget and future growth.
Content: As the Union Budget 2025 approaches, the Economic Survey takes centre stage in shaping the country’s financial outlook. Scheduled for presentation on January 31, a day before the budget, the Economic Survey provides essential insights into India’s economic health and sets the stage for the government’s fiscal plans.WHAT IS THE ECONOMIC SURVEY? The Economic Survey is a comprehensive review of India’s economic performance over the past fiscal year. It covers critical sectors such as agriculture, industry, and services, along with key economic indicators like GDP growth, inflation, employment rates, fiscal deficit, and more. The document, prepared by the Department of Economic Affairs under the supervision of the Chief Economic Advisor, V Anantha Nageswaran, includes policy recommendations to address economic challenges and promote growth. The survey is divided into two main sections: Part A reviews the country’s economic status, focusing on current fiscal trends, while Part B addresses socio-economic issues like education, poverty, climate change, and social security. Projections for GDP, inflation, forex reserves, and trade deficits are also included. The theme of this year’s Economic Survey is expected to focus on deregulation, which will likely influence the upcoming budget discussions.WHY IS THE ECONOMIC SURVEY IMPORTANT? The Economic Survey plays a pivotal role in shaping the Union Budget by offering a clear and unbiased assessment of the economy. It aids policymakers in making informed decisions and helps stakeholders such as investors and businesses with key economic data for strategic planning. The survey is not only a pre-budget tool but also an important benchmark for evaluating economic progress and setting future growth targets.HISTORICAL CONTEXT AND CONTINUED RELEVANCE Historically, the Economic Survey was presented alongside the Union Budget, but since 1964, it has been released a day before the budget. This document continues to be essential in guiding India’s economic policy and providing transparency to the nation’s financial landscape. As we await the Union Budget 2025, the Economic Survey offers valuable foresight, shaping not just the budget but the economic roadmap for the year ahead.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 8, 2025Must Watch

Headline: Instant loans for housewives: A step-by-step guideInstant personal loans offer housewives quick financial relief with easy application, affordable rates, and fast approval.
Content: Instant personal loans offer housewives quick financial relief with easy application, affordable rates, and fast approval. Being a homemaker is no easy task. Managing a household, caring for children, and supporting family members emotionally can be overwhelming, especially when unexpected expenses arise. In such times, instant personal loans can provide much-needed financial relief. This article offers a guide for housewives looking to secure instant loans and handle financial crises with ease.advertisementWHAT ARE INSTANT PERSONAL LOANS? Instant personal loans are short-term, unsecured loans designed to provide quick financial assistance. Unlike traditional loans, which require lengthy paperwork and approval processes, instant loans are processed through online platforms that make application and approval faster. With just a few clicks, housewives can apply for a loan and receive funds in their bank accounts within hours.KEY FEATURES OF INSTANT PERSONAL LOANS FOR HOUSEWIVES Affordable interest rates: Loans designed for women often come with lower interest rates, making them more affordable and easier to manage. Low processing fees: Financial institutions usually charge lower processing fees for loans targeted at women, which are clearly stated upfront. No collateral required: Instant loans do not require any collateral, reducing stress for housewives looking for financial assistance without risking valuable assets. Quick disbursement: Once approved, the loan amount is transferred to the borrower’s account within hours, providing immediate relief.REQUIRED DOCUMENTS Applying for an instant personal loan is a simple process that requires minimal documentation. You will need to provide basic identity proof, such as an Aadhaar card, passport, PAN card, or voter’s ID, along with address proof, which can include an Aadhaar card, passport, utility bill, or voter’s ID.HOW TO APPLY FOR INSTANT PERSONAL LOANS Applying for an instant personal loan is simple. Visit the website or mobile app of your chosen bank or lender. Log in with your registered mobile number. Select the option for an instant personal loan. Fill out the required details and upload the necessary documents. Once approved, the loan amount will be credited to your account.CONSIDERATIONS BEFORE APPLYING Before applying for an instant loan, ensure you consider the following: Repayment period: These loans typically come with a short repayment term, so choose one that suits your budget. Eligibility: Ensure you meet the eligibility criteria to avoid rejection, which can negatively impact your credit score. Terms & conditions: Always read the fine print to understand loan charges and conditions. Instant loans offer housewives a quick solution to financial challenges. By exploring online platforms and microfinance options, they can access funds for unplanned expenses and make informed decisions that align with their financial needs.Published By: Jasmine anandPublished On: Jan 8, 2025
